case_name: Messrs. Pratapray Manmohandas v. Bombay Bullion Association Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 437/60 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 437/60.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Bombay High Court judgment and decree dated July 12, 1957 in Appeal No. 71 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated July 12, 1957, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 71 of 1956.

facts.text: Appellant was trading under the name Messrs. Pratapray Manmohandas as bullion merchant in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, who was the plaintiff in the suit, was trading under the name and style of Messrs. Pratapray Manmohandas as a bullion merchant and trader in Bombay.

facts.text: Appellant was member of Bombay Bullion Association Ltd., defendant No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: He was a member of the Bombay Bullion Association Ltd., which was defendant No. 1 in the suit and is respondent No. 1 in the appeal.

facts.text: Respondents 2 to 7 were members of Clearing House Committee under bye-laws of 1st respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents 2 to 7 defendants 2 to 7 and at all material times were members of the Clearing House Committee appointed under the Bye-laws of the 1st respondent.

facts.text: Appellant entered forward transactions with defendants 8 to 12 from May 30, 1949 to June 30, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant entered into certain forward transactionswith defendants 8 to 12 during the period from May 30, 1949 to June 30, 1949.

facts.text: On June 13, 1949, Hawala rate of these transactions was fixed.

anchor.surface_text: On June 13, the Hawala rate of these transactions was fixed and on June 14, 1949,

facts.text: On June 14, 1949, appellant submitted clearance sheet under bye-law 131 including transactions with defendants 8 to 12.

anchor.surface_text: the applicant I admitted a clearance sheet under bye-law 131 of the bye-laws of 1st. respondent in which outstanding transactions for the Valan day  settlement  were entered.

facts.text: Transactions with defendants 8 to 12 were tallied on the following day.

anchor.surface_text: They included the transactions which had been entered into with defendants 8 to 12. All these transactions were Rajued  tallied  on the following day.

facts.text: Appellant did not include amounts due to defendants 8 to 12 in balance sheet, disputing transactions as fictitious and illegal.

anchor.surface_text: According to the bye-laws of the respondent Association lie balance sheet, had to be submitted and money Kiplis  vouchers  had to be given. In this balance sheet which was submitted the appellant did number include the amounts which were due to defendants Nos. 8 to 12 or the transactions he had entered into on the ground that he disputed the transactions entered into with those defendants as they were fictitious and illegal.

facts.text: On June 21, 1949, Valan day settlement day, appellant claimed reference to arbitration under bye-law 38 regarding those items.

anchor.surface_text: On June 21, 1994 , which was the Valan day  settlement day  the appellant claimed reference to arbitration in regard to those items under bye-law 38.

facts.text: On June 21, 1949, defendants 8 to 12 complained to respondent Association that appellant had not issued kaplis vouchers.

anchor.surface_text: On that day defendants 8 to 12 companyplained to the respondent Association that the appellant had number issued the necessary kaplis  vouchers .

facts.text: At 3 p.m. on June 21, 1949, appellant received notice from Clearing House Committee to appear before them.

anchor.surface_text: At 3 p. m. on the same day the appellant received a numberice from the Clearing House Committee, respondents 2 to 7 calling upon him to appear before them.

facts.text: Appellant appeared before Clearing House Committee with solicitor and counsel on June 21, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant appeared with his solicitor and companynsel, and his companytention before the Clearing House Committee

facts.text: Appellant contended Clearing House Committee had no jurisdiction due to arbitration claim.

anchor.surface_text: was that it had numberjurisdiction to proceed with the matter because he was claiming arbitration and the dispute between him and defendants 8 to 12 had to be settled by the arbitrators.

facts.text: Clearing House Committee declared appellant a defaulter under bye-law 155(4) on June 21, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The Committee heard the explanation and passed a resolution under byelaw 155  4  declaring the plaintiff a defaulter and it is this resolution which is the matter in companytroversy between the parties,

facts.text: Appellant filed suit on June 20, 1952 for declaration that resolution dated June 21, 1949 was bad, inoperative, ultra vires, not binding, and for damages and reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: On June. 20, 1952, the appellant brought a suit for declaration that the resolution in dispute dated June 21, 1949, was bad in law, inoperative, ultra vires and number binding on the appellant and also for damages against the respondents. He also prayed for reinstatement as a member of the respondent Association.

facts.text: Suit tried by Tendolkar J., appellant led no evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was tried by Tendolkar J. Several issues were raised but the appellant led numberevidence

facts.text: Suit dismissed on June 6, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On June 6, 1956, the suit was dismissed and an appeal was taken to the Appeal Court

facts.text: Appeal to Bombay High Court dismissed, confirming trial court decree.

anchor.surface_text: which was also dismissed and the appellant has companye in appeal by Special Leave.

facts.text: Trial court held appellant's plea that hearing proceeded in absence after they left not established.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt had held that the plea taken by the appellant that after he and his companynsel were heard they were made to leave the meeting and the hearing proceeded in their absence was number established

facts.text: Appellant voluntarily left meeting after indicating unwillingness to submit kaplis.

anchor.surface_text: issue No. 5 was specific on this point. That issue was whether the appellant and his legal advisers voluntarily left the meeting after indicating that the appellant was number going to give the kaplis

facts.text: Settlement had to be made by 3:30 p.m. on June 21, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: According to the chart of Bombay Bullion exchange settlement had to be made, i. e. the monies had to be paid by 3-30 p.m. on June 21, 1949.

facts.text: Appellant stated he would not pay on Valan day but after arbitration award.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant made it clear, however, that he was number going to make the payment in accordance with the requirements of the Valan day on the other hand he stated that he will pay after the arbitration award was made.

facts.text: Evidence of Mr. Trikamdas Dwarkadas, solicitor present at meeting on June 21, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: That clause requires that in the event of default of submission of a kapli the Clearing House Committee shall call the defaulter and demand an explanation and thereafter, if such kapli is number submitted, declare him a defaulter.

arguments.claim: Question of interpretation of bye-law 155(4) (appeal ground 1)

anchor.surface_text: Two questions have been raised in this appeal, (1) the question of interpretation and (2) that no opportunity was given after the decision was made against the appellant to give the kaplis.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees explanation first then opportunity, but clarifies no fixed time

holdings.text: The finding of both the courts that the appellant and his legal advisers voluntarily left the meeting after indicating unwillingness to submit kaplis is fully justified by the evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrt below have found that whether an opportunity held been given to the appellant or number, he had numberinterim of giving him kaplis. issue No. 5 was specific on this point. That issue was whether the appellant and his legal advisers voluntarily left the meeting after indicating that the appellant was number going to give the kaplis and that was the, principal question which has been raised throughout the companyrse of these proceedings. Even in the statement of the appellants case he as put in the forefront of the question for decision the question whether the appellant left the meeting dated June 21, 1949, voluntarily after indicating his unwillingness to submit the kaplis. finding of both the companyrts, on this question was against the appellant. In our opinion that is fully justified by the evidence on the record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence including attendance book, minutes, and appellant's statements confirm voluntary departure after refusal.

holdings.text: The contentions that transactions were fictitious were false and raised to gain time; no genuine dispute under bye-law 38.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Transactions entered in clearance sheet, tallied, acknowledged in books despite claims.

holdings.text: The respondent Association was justified in taking the action declaring the appellant a defaulter.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Association was therefore justified in taking the action that it did. The minutes of the proceedings of the Clearing House Committee dated June 21, 1949, also show that the appellant and his legal advisers stated that they wanted to go to arbitration and that numberaction should be taken against them until the arbitrators had given their award.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant refused payment on Valan day, demanded arbitration first; procedure followed.

holdings.text: Bye-law 155(4) requires calling for explanation first, then after assessing validity of reasons, opportunity to submit kapli; no fixed specific time required.

anchor.surface_text: Bye-law 155 4 reads If any member does number submit a kapli in the prescribed form in respect of the amount found claimable from him to his party creditor , the Clearing House Committee shall call him and demand an explanation from him and can thereafter, if such a kapli is number submitted the Clearing House Committee can declare him a defaulter. That clause requires that in the event of default of submission of a kapli the Clearing House Committee shall call the defaulter and demand an explanation and thereafter, if such kapli is number submitted, declare him a defaulter. It was companytended that the meaning of this is that first the Clearing House Committee is to demand an explanation and after such an explanation is given,. time has to be given for the purpose of enabling the person number giving the kapli to. submit his kaplis.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation in consonance with High Court; opportunity after explanation but flexible time based on circumstances.

holdings.text: No further opportunity required after explanation where clear no intention to pay; giving time futile given settlement deadlines.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the interpretation of the learned Chief Justice of the High Court is in companysonance with the language used. i. e. first the explanation is called and after explanation is given and some decision is arrived at in regard to the validity of the reasons for number giving the kaplis then the person companyplained against can file the kapli but it does number mean that the time to be given has to be one or half an hour or any other specific period. As we have said above the appellant had made it clear that he was number going to make the payment and had just left after making his submissions. It is number a requirement of the bye- law that the Clearing House Committee should call the person defaulting either by telephone or by letter or by giving him a numberice and companysidering the promptitude with which the payments have to be made and the dates fixed for the finishing of all the transactions it will be unreasonable to hold that such is the procedure companytemplated by cl.  4  of bye-law 155. The period of time, must, in each case, depend upon the circumstances, but where it is made absolutely clear that numberpayment is going to be made the giving of time is wholly without utility.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant's conduct showed no intention; deadlines make fixed procedure unreasonable; opportunity was given but futile.

holdings.text: Clearing House Committee did not act without due consideration or precipitately.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances it cannot be said that the respondent Committee acted without giving due companysideration to the facts of the case or in any precipitate manner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Heard explanation, considered arbitration claim and records showing genuine transactions.

anchor.surface_text: Bye-law 155 4 reads If any member does number submit a kapli in the prescribed form in respect of the amount found claimable from him to his party creditor , the Clearing House Committee shall call him and demand an explanation from him and can thereafter, if such a kapli is number submitted the Clearing House Committee can declare him a defaulter. That clause requires that in the event of default of submission of a kapli the Clearing House Committee shall call the defaulter and demand an explanation and thereafter, if such kapli is number submitted, declare him a defaulter. It was companytended that the meaning of this is that first the Clearing House Committee is to demand an explanation and after such an explanation is given,. time has to be given for the purpose of enabling the person number giving the kapli to. submit his kaplis.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the interpretation of the learned Chief Justice of the High Court is in companysonance with the language used. i. e. first the explanation is called and after explanation is given and some decision is arrived at in regard to the validity of the reasons for number giving the kaplis then the person companyplained against can file the kapli but it does number mean that the time to be given has to be one or half an hour or any other specific period. As we have said above the appellant had made it clear that he was number going to make the payment and had just left after making his submissions. It is number a requirement of the bye- law that the Clearing House Committee should call the person defaulting either by telephone or by letter or by giving him a numberice and companysidering the promptitude with which the payments have to be made and the dates fixed for the finishing of all the transactions it will be unreasonable to hold that such is the procedure companytemplated by cl.  4  of bye-law 155. The period of time, must, in each case, depend upon the circumstances, but where it is made absolutely clear that numberpayment is going to be made the giving of time is wholly without utility.
